fr:title.text: Bicategories are virtual bicategories with all composites

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Bicategories are virtual bicategories with all composites

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A bicategory is the same thing as a virtual bicategory that has all composites, as observed by Derek Elkins.
A directed graph G is defined to be a collection of 0-cells A,B,C,\ldots \in G together with a collection of edges {A}\xrightarrow {{e}}{B}\in G.

fr:title.text: Free category on a directed graph

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Free category on a directed graph

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a directed graph; a path in G is defined to be a sequence of compatible edges {\mathopen {}\left [A_0\xrightarrow {f_0}A_1\xrightarrow {f_1}\ldots \xrightarrow {f_{n-1}}A_n\right ]\mathclose {}}. Evidently, the free category G^{\star } on G has morphisms given by paths.
A virtual bicategory \mathcal {K} is a directed graph equipped with the following additional data:

html:ol.html:li: for each path {A}\xrightarrow {{\Psi }}{B}\in \mathcal {K}^{\star } and each edge {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B}\in \mathcal {K}, a collection of 2-cells {\Psi }\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{f}\in \mathcal {K}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}};
for any edge {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B}, an identity 2-cell {{\mathopen {}\left [f\right ]\mathclose {}}}\xrightarrow {{1_{f}}}{f}\in \mathcal {K}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}};

for any sequence of compatible paths A_0\xrightarrow {\Psi _0}\ldots \xrightarrow {\Psi _{n-1}}A_n\in \mathcal {K}^{\star } and 2-cells {\Psi _i}\xrightarrow {{\alpha _i}}{f_i}\in \mathcal {K}{\mathopen {}\left (A_i,A_{i+1}\right )\mathclose {}} and {{\mathopen {}\left [f_i\mid i<n\right ]\mathclose {}}}\xrightarrow {{\beta }}{g}\in \mathcal {K}{\mathopen {}\left (A_0,A_n\right )\mathclose {}}, a composite 2-cell {\Psi _0;\ldots ;\Psi _n}\xrightarrow {{{\mathopen {}\left [\alpha _i\mid i<n\right ]\mathclose {}};\beta }}{g};
such that the composition of 2-cells is both associative and unital with respect to identity 2-cells.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {K} be a virtual bicategory; given a path {A}\xrightarrow {{\Psi }}{B}\in \mathcal {K}^{\star } and an edge {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B}, a 2-cell {\Psi }\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{f} is called cocartesian if any 2-cell {\Phi ;\Psi ;\Xi }\xrightarrow {{\beta }}{s} factors uniquely through \alpha in the sense that there exists a unique 2-cell {\Phi ;{\mathopen {}\left [f\right ]\mathclose {}};\Xi }\xrightarrow {{\beta \setminus \alpha }}{s} such that \beta = {\mathopen {}\left [\overrightarrow {1_{\Phi _i}\ldots },\alpha ,\overrightarrow {1_{\Xi _i}\ldots }\right ]\mathclose {}};{\mathopen {}\left (\beta \setminus \alpha \right )\mathclose {}}.

fr:title.text: Left- and right-cocartesian 2-cells in a virtual bicategory

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Left- and right-cocartesian 2-cells in a virtual bicategory

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {K} be a virtual bicategory; given a path {A}\xrightarrow {{\Psi }}{B}\in \mathcal {K}^{\star } and an edge {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B}, a 2-cell {\Psi }\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{f} is called left-cocartesian if for 2-cell {\Psi ;\Xi }\xrightarrow {{\beta }}{s} factors uniquely through \alpha in the sense that there exists a unique 2-cell {{\mathopen {}\left [f\right ]\mathclose {}};\Psi }\xrightarrow {{\beta \setminus \alpha }}{s} such that \beta = {\mathopen {}\left [\alpha ,\overrightarrow {1_{\Xi _i}\ldots }\right ]\mathclose {}};{\mathopen {}\left (\beta \setminus \alpha \right )\mathclose {}}.

Dually, given a path {B}\xrightarrow {{\Psi }}{C}\in \mathcal {K}^{\star } and an edge {B}\xrightarrow {{f}}{C}, a 2-cell {\Psi }\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{f} is called right-cocartesian if for 2-cell {\Phi ;\Psi }\xrightarrow {{\beta }}{s} factors uniquely through \alpha in the sense that there exists a unique 2-cell {\Phi ;{\mathopen {}\left [f\right ]\mathclose {}}}\xrightarrow {{\beta \setminus \alpha }}{s} such that \beta = {\mathopen {}\left [\overrightarrow {1_{\Phi _i}\ldots },\alpha \right ]\mathclose {}};{\mathopen {}\left (\beta \setminus \alpha \right )\mathclose {}}.
These definitions are due to Arkor and McDermott.
Let \mathcal {K} be a virtual bicategory, and let {A}\xrightarrow {{\Psi }}{B}\in \mathcal {K}^{\star } be a path in \mathcal {K}. Then we define:

html:ol.html:li: a composite of \Psi is a cocartesian 2-cell with domain \Psi ;
a left half-composite of \Psi is a left-cocartesian 2-cell with domain \Psi ;
a right half-composite of \Psi is a right-cocartesian 2-cell with domain \Psi .

fr:title.text: Bicategories are virtual bicategories with all composites

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Bicategories are virtual bicategories with all composites

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A bicategory is the same thing as a virtual bicategory that has all composites, as observed by Derek Elkins.

I still don't know if the following are the correct definitions. One would have to check that the left-composite of a pair of maps is isomorphic to the right-composite if both exist, which sounds plausible.

fr:title.text: Thunkable and linear maps in a virtual bicategory

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Thunkable and linear maps in a virtual bicategory

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {K} be a virtual bicategory; we isolate two classes of edges:

html:ol.html:li: an edge {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B} in \mathcal {K} is called thunkable if and only if for any edge {B}\xrightarrow {{g}}{C} there exists a left half-composite {{\mathopen {}\left [f;g\right ]\mathclose {}}}\xrightarrow {{\lambda }}{h};

dually, an edge {B}\xrightarrow {{g}}{C} in \mathcal {K} is called linear if and only if for any edge {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B} there exists a right half-composite {{\mathopen {}\left [f;g\right ]\mathclose {}}}\xrightarrow {{\rho }}{h}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {K} be a virtual bicategory; we isolate two classes of objects in \mathcal {K}, by analogy with the case for deductive systems:

html:ol.html:li: an object B\in \mathcal {K} is called positive when every edge {B}\xrightarrow {{f}}{C} is linear;
an object B\in \mathcal {K} is called negative when every edge {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B} is thunkable.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Then we say that an object is polarized when it is either positive or negative in the above sense.
Let \mathcal {K} be a virtual bicategory, and let {A}\xrightarrow {{\Psi }}{B}\in \mathcal {K}^{\star } be a path in \mathcal {K}. Then we define:

html:ol.html:li: a composite of \Psi is a cocartesian 2-cell with domain \Psi ;
a left half-composite of \Psi is a left-cocartesian 2-cell with domain \Psi ;
a right half-composite of \Psi is a right-cocartesian 2-cell with domain \Psi .

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A virtual bicategory \mathcal {K} is a directed graph equipped with the following additional data:

html:ol.html:li: for each path {A}\xrightarrow {{\Psi }}{B}\in \mathcal {K}^{\star } and each edge {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B}\in \mathcal {K}, a collection of 2-cells {\Psi }\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{f}\in \mathcal {K}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}};
for any edge {A}\xrightarrow {{f}}{B}, an identity 2-cell {{\mathopen {}\left [f\right ]\mathclose {}}}\xrightarrow {{1_{f}}}{f}\in \mathcal {K}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}};

for any sequence of compatible paths A_0\xrightarrow {\Psi _0}\ldots \xrightarrow {\Psi _{n-1}}A_n\in \mathcal {K}^{\star } and 2-cells {\Psi _i}\xrightarrow {{\alpha _i}}{f_i}\in \mathcal {K}{\mathopen {}\left (A_i,A_{i+1}\right )\mathclose {}} and {{\mathopen {}\left [f_i\mid i<n\right ]\mathclose {}}}\xrightarrow {{\beta }}{g}\in \mathcal {K}{\mathopen {}\left (A_0,A_n\right )\mathclose {}}, a composite 2-cell {\Psi _0;\ldots ;\Psi _n}\xrightarrow {{{\mathopen {}\left [\alpha _i\mid i<n\right ]\mathclose {}};\beta }}{g};
such that the composition of 2-cells is both associative and unital with respect to identity 2-cells.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A bicategory B is given by the following structure and axioms:

html:ol.html:li: a collection of objects x,y,z called 0-cells;
for each pair of 0-cells x,y a category \mathbf {hom}_{B}{\mathopen {}\left (x,y\right )\mathclose {}} of morphisms or 1-cells x\xrightarrow {f}y;
for each object x, a morphism x\xrightarrow {1_{x}}x called the identity morphism;

for all objects x,y,z, a functor \mathbf {hom}_{B}{\mathopen {}\left (x,y\right )\mathclose {}}\times \mathbf {hom}_{B}{\mathopen {}\left (y,z\right )\mathclose {}}\xrightarrow {{\mathopen {}\left (\mathbin {\boldsymbol {;}}\right )\mathclose {}}}\mathbf {hom}_{B}{\mathopen {}\left (x,z\right )\mathclose {}} called horizontal composition;

for all 1-morphisms e\xrightarrow {f}x\xrightarrow {g}y\xrightarrow {h}z, an isomorphism {\mathopen {}\left (f\mathbin {\boldsymbol {;}} g\right )\mathclose {}}\mathbin {\boldsymbol {;}} h \xrightarrow {\alpha _{f,g,h}} f\mathbin {\boldsymbol {;}}{\mathopen {}\left (g\mathbin {\boldsymbol {;}} h\right )\mathclose {}} natural in f,g,h called the associator;
for all 1-morphisms x\xrightarrow {f}y, an isomorphism 1_{x}\mathbin {\boldsymbol {;}} f\xrightarrow {\lambda _{f}} f natural in f called the left unitor;
for all 1-morphisms x\xrightarrow {f}y, an isomorphism f\mathbin {\boldsymbol {;}}1_{y}\xrightarrow {\rho _{f}} f natural in f called the right unitor;
